title: the crime with new runes

POWER CREEP??
you mean putting us to square 1?
If four kids each have a slice of food it's "balanced". One kid gets another slice, so you give the other three another slice as well. It's not square one, you just increased overall power.

But you didn't. Consider it like this. 

You have runes and masteries right now.

You remove both of them and create the new runes.

New runes are for the most part just refined masteries. They have roughly the same amount of stat power amongst them with only slightly increased values here and there.

Then you have runes missing. Some of the power is there in the new runes but it is faaaaar from there.

So you put some power onto each champion via base buffs and you restore them back to their base value.

You are then at square one.
In my opinion new runes add a large amount of power and Riot is planning on buffing the champions that need it further.

The whole new rune page is basically just a slightly better Mastery Page. Champions will see slight increases to their bases to be in line with old runes but its still a large nerf since you can't say go 20 armor as a tank into a really rough match-up. Or you being unable to grab HP over armor into APs. You lose the ability to truly alter your base stats and are kind of screwed at times. The new runes and buffs to base stats, which won't be much and the numbers of runes are very likely to change, are just equal to current power at best. The only thing that is really getting a good buff is ADCs.

Yo, I totally understand your concerns if you're just looking at the rune builder on the website for sure. 

As others have mentioned, we are making pretty significant adjustments to base stats across the board to keep the early game feeling similar to live right now (and will continue to do so through out Preseason). I _think_ the plan is to spit those changes out in chat at the beginning of the game for PBE (inelegant, but effective) so you can tell how your champion has been changed.

There are also some handy Armor & MR options in Resolve, which is more of a defensively oriented tree if you want to play to a specific lane match up. However, if your mindset is "no one takes green as a side" you'll probably miss out on those? We've found in testing so far that many players are opting into/changing to the Resolve Path as a secondary for some extra security in more difficult matchups.

Is there a reason why the resolve tree runes Iron skin and Mirror shell are basically the same thing but just for a different defensive stat? Also the Conditioning rune has somewhat same effect after 10 minutes but just better since it gives both armor and mr. To me these runes sound very uninteractive compared to the others.

Why not try something more interactive? Every 30 seconds you get a shield that mitigates 50-75% of the damage from the next damage source from enemy champion. Or maybe something like an adaptive shield that buffs the resistance you least have.

There needs to be more reasons to pick resolve as secondary path for squishy characters. % based resistance increase is hardly worth considering.

Well honestly, we found that some players actually prefer flat stats and enjoyed that part of the old runes system. Also, with 6 different runes in a page, not everyone wanted a super interactive thing in every slot (that's a lot of extra stuff to think about). 

There are more active options for defense if that's your jam (ex: Nullifying Orb) but we are trying to have a mix of runes you really need to think about and runes that you can kinda set and forget. 

Also for Iron Skin and Mirror Shell, the idea is for a bit of a 'reactive' choice - i.e you use your knowledge of the opponent to change this option from game to game. When comparing both of these to something like Conditioning, the question I usually ask myself is "do I think I can keep myself from getting wrecked long enough for Conditioning to kick in? Or do I need that protection immediately from level 1 to stay safe?" 

Hope that answers your questions a little bit, but happy to chat more with the design logic behind stuff. :)

about nullifying orb, why only make it block magic damage?
Isn't doing a camille like shield (base on incoming damage) better?

feels like this rune should have a physical counterpart because of how easy it is to proc (shield that proc themselves are the one I find the least interesting so, if ad another, why is it to be a second hexdrinker only)

I fear that ad vs ap matchup will be even more braindead now itemisation wise :s

If I take 20 mpen in starting runes, it's literally not possible for you to adjust base stats enough to compensate for that loss. I thought we would at least keep the Precision mastery as a rune, but even that's out the window.

So in literally 100% of my games, I just straight-up lose 20-26 flat pen. MR reduction from base stat tinkering *might* make up for 5-10 of that.

The simple fact is that I am now starting off weaker in all of my games, and every item purchase throughout the game will result in a weaker power spike. What's worse is that - as a whole - the new runes don't come close to replacing what I lose, and I can't find a single new rune that has obvious synergy with my main champ. 

It's not like this issue wasn't on your radar.

> [{quoted}](name=Meddler,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=vNFRvIEM,comment-id=000000000000000000010000,timestamp=2017-09-20T18:06:26.668+0000)

Umm...ok? Lowering MR by a few points doesn't account for the loss of 20-26 pen. It's just a pure nerf. If Riot did manage to keep pen mages at the status quo through base stats, that ends up being a buff to AP-scaling mages that would have otherwise had to chew through higher base MR. It's just math. 

Now that we know there are no pen runes, can anyone at Riot be bothered to acknowledge the nerf to pen mages and rationalize it with numbers?

On another note, what does it take to get a simple question answered? I politely asked devs about this in 14 different threads over the course of 3 months, beginning the same day as the reforged announcement. At no point has anyone addressed or acknowledged the fact that this is a substantial nerf to a few champs. Does this seem reasonable or fair to you?

However my 2nd concern is still champs who wanted 15-20% early game CDR. I'm going to be watching them closely as to how they'll perform without  it.

And even more than that, my #1 concern are hybrid champs will they become busted with the changes or lose out on the changes... My main hybrid champ being shaco, I more than loved having an extra 24 lethality, 40 AP(lvl 18), 8 AD(lvl 18) in a game just from runes and masteries

You're forgetting everyone got -9/-12 but there's no AD/AP quints or stacking runes anymore or anything like that. You won't be able to load up on +20 AD at level one, is what I'm getting at.

The balance for the rune system happens in two hands where I see it, one is to give everyone access to simpler and more pronounced effects, the other is to pull the game away from behind-the-scenes numbers like Runes-- now I know Lucian took Looter (random example), I'm not poring over his stats and trying to piece together where his runes/masteries fall.

The _real_ crime is that they didn't announce it by saying 'We're about to Rune League of Legends. Forever.'
